Fields.DialogueText: How is the refit treating you, Gnevny? I've seen your crew running drills on the new anti-aircraft guns.
Yes, well, that seemed like the sort of thing you would tell me I needed to do, so I decided to beat you to it.
Be careful, Gnevny. You're starting to sound like a responsible member of the Fleet.
Bah, I am always responsible, Kapitan. It is others who are not as responsible who cause my issues.
Of course, Gnevny, of course. Now, about the refit?
Ah, yes, Kapitan. It seems like everything is in order. The crew appreciate that I do not leak nearly so much.
What about the weaponry? Is it up to your standards? No more nightmares about the skies?
No, Kapitan, I think things are going to be different from here on out. I'm excited to see how well they perform.

Fields.MenuText: It just goes to show you what you can accomplish when you are honest with your friends.
I'm glad to hear it, Gnevny. Having all of my ships in working order is very important to me.
The squeaky wheel gets the grease, Gnevny. Eventually, at least.

Fields.DialogueText: Stop hammering me with lessons already, Kapitan. I am not an idiot.
Yes, yes, good work, Kapitan, you made me more useful to you.
Thank you for letting me know you think I'm annoying, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
Oh, there's the alarm. It looks like you'll get a chance to put your new gear to the test.
Rusalki svin'i! I'll paint the coasts with your blood!
Well, now that that's out of your system...
That was me getting it back in my system! I was choking on all this proklyatyy civility.
@BATTLE
How was the christening? Your crew seemed very jovial when I saw them earlier.
Oh, the guns performed well, Kapitan. The crew also. They seem pleased.
Fantastic. I expect you're eager to get back out there and do some damage with your new gun complement?
Oh, of course, Kapitan. Anything for the Fleet.
You don't seem as excited as I thought you'd be. Don't get me wrong, I'm not complaining.
There's nothing wrong with not being too eager for the fray, after all.
Oh, it's not that. I'm happy to blow up whatever you point me at.

Fields.MenuText: Didn't we just have a long series of conversations about how you should trust me when things are bothering you?
This had better not be something that endangers the fleet, Gnevny.
You know you can tell me if there is a problem, right, Gnevny?

Fields.DialogueText: Shut up, Kapitan! I haven't done anything. It is just fine.
I would never! Why can't you just trust me, Kapitan? I am a part of the Fleet as well.
There is no problem, Kapitan. Everything will be just fine, I promise.
*ALARM*
All right. There's the alarm. Let's go do our jobs and we'll worry about this later.
What was that?
Urge to destroy rising...
Oh, nothing you personally need to worry about.
@BATTLE
Gnevny, are you out here? The seas are looking rather rough tonight.
Do you have any information that I don't? I can feel the sea lapping at my hull.
Smoking again as well? I'm a little worried about light discipline out here, but I suppose it's not that big of an issue.
Are you going to give me a way into this conversation at some point, or will you continue completing both sides?
Someone is certainly cranky today. Has your cigarette guy not been keeping you stocked up?
I have ample supplies, Kapitan. And if I told you more, I feel you would try to take them away from me.

Fields.MenuText: I have better things to do than to try and steal your cigarettes away.
Maybe I'd just try to get my own, hmm? You aren't the only one with vices.
It'd be better to try to cut myself in on their action. I'm sure your supplier is making a killing if they can get cigarettes out here.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you? You seem to be lurking around my decks with nothing productive to do.
Don't come to me and try to take one. I do not support charity cases.
That's... charmingly cynical,  Kapitan. I'm almost impressed.
There's the alarm. I suppose we'll have to talk more later. Get your crew to their posts, will you?
Of course, Kapitan. And I suppose light discipline is a little bit less important now, isn't it?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You always seem to get your way one way or another.
My way is easier if you give it to me, Kapitan.
Gnevny! Where are you? You've missed two briefings already, and I'm starting to worry about you. Some of the crew said you would be down here. Are you in the magazine?
Stop yelling, Kapitan. I'm right here.
At least you aren't smoking in here anymore. What's happening, Gnevny? Where have you been?
I have been here, Kapitan. There is no need to worry about me. Everything is just fine.
Then why are you hiding? The crew doesn't seem to know where you are, and you don't answer summons. You are simply disappearing when there's no battle on the horizon.
That is ridiculous, Kapitan. I am always available if you bother to look for me.

Fields.MenuText: We both know that's not true, given the amount of time I just spent trying to find you.
You can blame others if you want, but we both know that you're avoiding contact.
This is a war, Gnevny. There is no time for a hissy fit.

Fields.DialogueText: You are making assumptions with no data, Kapitan. No one accepts your stories as fact.
I am not blaming others! I am fine!
Shut up, Kapitan! I am not throwing a hissy fit! I am fighting a proper war, and I am a proper ship!
*ALARM*
We'll have to talk about this later. Find you and we find a battle, apparently.
@BATTLE
Or else.
Hah! I found you this time, Gnevny. We're going to have a talk.
Oh, please spare me, Kapitan. What have I done to deserve another round of being told I should stop sulking?
Answered your own question, didn't you?
All this down time doesn't make you... itchy?
Itchy?
I'm starting to see why you put me through those tests, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Because I value the lives of my crew?
Because you were in dire need of improvement?
Because the other Belles were complaining?

Fields.DialogueText: If they valued their lives, they'd stay out of my way when I'm performing maintenance.
Hey! I was doing the very best with what those Zhdanov goons gave me!
Bunch of glorified dinghies. I'd like to see them handle a tenth of the nonsense I go through.
Am I?
Think of how long it took you to convince me to open up about my refit. I needed to know I could trust your intentions. But you persevered.
You know, Kapitan, you're a lot like me.
You may pretend to be stuffy and insecure and scared of every little rusty rivet--
I believe you had a point to make.
Konechno. Beneath that wishy-washy exterior is a thirst to prove yourself. If you're not constantly fighting for your life, what are you alive for?
*ALARM*
Now's really not the best time for philosophy.
When ever is it? I'm just glad I have something to shoot.
@BATTLE
Do you smell that, Kapitan?
Sea salt?
Cowardice.
Whose?
I can't be certain. I just need to be ready to beat it out of them when I find them.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you're telling me about this before I have to clean up the consequences.
Have you considered that you might scare people?
I thought you and the crew were on good terms.

Fields.DialogueText: When I deal with these things, I do not leave anything to clean up.
Why should anyone be afraid of me? I'm the one thing holding them back from the brink by the scruffs of their necks.
Why do you assume that it's the crew? Is there something you're not telling me?
Well, we'll talk about this in a bit. I think destroying some Morganas should give anyone some courage.
@BATTLE
And after that?
Well, if you'd like you can help me with the after action report.
Oil on a bonfire.
Well, there you have it, don't you, Gnevny?
There I have what, Kapitan? We didn't talk about anything. I don't understand.
Everyone pulled their weight in that battle, didn't you? Kept your sisters safe and pounded the Morganas?
I suppose there wasn't anything flagrantly wrong.
I just wish you'd tell me what's bothering you.
Why does it have to be anything in particular? Maybe I'm just generally on edge.

Fields.MenuText: You're the most confident Belle I know.
Well, if you happen to nail it down, let me know.
That can't be comfortable.

Fields.DialogueText: And don't you forget it!
If I do, you won't have to.
Who says life has to be comfortable? The minute you let your guard down, you're begging the Rusalki to devour you.
*ALARM*
Damn. I feel like we were making progress. Look over there, Gnevny. That's our target.
What are you talking about, Kapitan? All I see are rocks.
The Morganas. They're there on the horizon, see?
... Da. Of course, Kapitan. I was just trying to see if you knew.
@BATTLE
It's been good seeing you at the briefings, Gnevny. You're a good influence on your crew.
Well, I suppose it's my responsibility to make sure every part of myself is running well, isn't it?
I can't say I disagree with you, Gnevny. And I really do appreciate the work you've been putting in with your drills.
Hmph. I should hope so.
Say, is that our helmsman down at the other end of the ship?
You tell me, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: You don't recognize him?
I think he wants to tell us something.
No, you tell me.

Fields.DialogueText: People come and go. How am I supposed to memorize every single one that thinks they have what it takes to crew me?
Then he can come down here. I don't have the time for silly games of charades.
Is this some sort of test, Kapitan? I'm afraid I don't see the point.
How many fingers is he holding up?
Four, obviously.
Let's see if you're right... oh. He flew away.
This proves nothing.
That was a seabird, Gnevny, not our helmsman. You mind telling me why you couldn't tell?
I wasn't taking your games seriously, that's all.
*ALARM*
Chert. Rusalki. And I was so looking forward to continuing this pointless conversation.
For once we agree.
@BATTLE
Smoking out on the foredeck? Where everyone can see you? How very strange.
Give it a rest, Kapitan. I thought I'd take a page from the crew's book.
Who are you, and what have you done with Gnevny?
Yes, yes, very funny. Look, I noticed that many of the crew take their smoking time in this area. It seemed only natural to sort of... do as they do.
I definitely approve of building a sense of camaraderie among the crew, Gnevny. And not smoking by explosives.
You will never let that go, will you?

Fields.MenuText: In my defense, you could have blown us all to pieces.
Oh, I'm sure I'll eventually get tired of bringing it up. But not yet, that's for certain.
Maybe, if you do something even more terrifying and humorous.

Fields.DialogueText: You worry like an old grandmother. We were just fine.
The Romanovs dwelled on the past too, you know.
Your sense of humor has issues.
You aren't just out here to meet the person who brings you cigarettes, are you?
Oh, is that the alarm?
@BATTLE
What are you talking ab--
*ALARM*
See? Now, come on! Less questions and more gunfire.
*ALARM*
General quarters, everyone! This is going to be a rough fight!
Da! Up and at 'em!
@BATTLE
That was a great shot out there today. You blew that monster right out of the water!
I suppose I did, didn't I? It was not too difficult. I just fired when I needed to and got a clean hit.
Difficult or not, you definitely more than pulled your weight out there. You should be proud.
Of course I'm proud! Don't be patronizing.

Fields.MenuText: You mistook a seabird for your helmsman.
You're endangering the fleet by keeping this from me.
Perfectly nearsighted.

Fields.DialogueText: Kakaya raznitsa? It's not the helmsman I'm looking for when we fight!
And you're underestimating me at every turn! Where is the help in that?
... Near perfect!
Are we going to go through this again? We had enough trouble getting you to let us inspect you for a refit.
Proud or not, we still need to talk about your eyesight.
If you want to bore yourself to tears or be overcome with wonder. My eyesight is perfect.
Come to think of it, why didn't you bring this up when you put together your wish list?
Because I can fight just fine the way I am! The Rusalki are evil and ugly and you don't need eyes to shoot at what your soul deplores!
... Have you ever considered a career in propaganda?
When my cigarettes run out early, I'm blaming you.
I know of a few, actually. Graf Spee, for one. Conte di Cavour. Shigure.
All of whom are fascist hens scarcely worth the steel they're made of. Why would I emulate them?
Because they can fight at their maximum range?
Ha! Range is for cowards who can't take a punch up close!

Fields.MenuText: Tell that to the next Morgana submarine who catches wind of your eye problem.
So your plan is to run up to the Morganas and let them have it.
I think the idea is to avoid taking punches where possible.

Fields.DialogueText: I won't tell her, Kapitan! Will you?
My top speed exceeded expectations, I'll have you know.
Shows what you know. That's what armor is for.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. Are you at least going to shoot where you're told?
My crew do not tell me where to shoot! They give me advice and I decide whether to take it.
@BATTLE
I'm telling you, I don't need glasses! Who ever heard of a First Comrade wearing glasses?
Then you're more agreeable than I thought you were.
Well, if I can blow up a Rusalka I'm not going to say no.
Good. You won't find any from me. Is this what's had you so on edge lately?
What, the eyesight thing?
It's more than just a "thing." The gunnery crew can fire well enough, but what do you think of their performance?
Honestly?
Say anything.
Every miss makes me want to stuff them into my guns and fire them into the Baltic.

Fields.MenuText: All right, now we're getting somewhere.
So why not correct them?
Please don't do that.

Fields.DialogueText: Unless you're going to give me permission to do it, I don't see how.
If it were that simple I would have done it already!
Oh, you don't have to worry about that, Kapitan. I've resented you for it for this entire tour.
What's wrong with pointing the crew in the right direction?
And let them see that I'm just as blind as they are!?
I don't need your pity, Kapitan.
Der'mo. You really are persistent, aren't you?
Almost as persistent as these Morganas.
Fine. We'll talk later about my... situation. But not a word to the crew, do you hear me?
My lips are sealed.
Shame. I was kind of looking forward to sealing them for you.
@BATTLE
Notice the decorations?
I see the posters around my structure. They're giving me an awful itch.
Maybe it'll cancel out the itch of your boredom.
If everything that annoyed me worked that way, I'd be the picture of inner peace, and therefore useless in a fight.
You don't think you'd fight better against others once you conquer yourself?
I've conquered myself. It's the crew I want to fight.
You mean you want to teach them to be better.
I mean I want to throw them overboard and let them swim back to beg forgiveness.

Fields.MenuText: And here I thought you were getting along with them.
For obvious reasons, I can't let you do that.
I'm sure we can find a compromise.

Fields.DialogueText: I am! Mostly. When they treat me correctly.
Stupid reasons.
Keelhauling them?
Just do me a favor. After the next time you're out here smoking, tell me which posters you can read clearly and where you can read them from.
Hmm. It'll give you a sense of what my eyes are like without alerting the crew.
It'll be no different than rearranging furniture.
It used to be that I wouldn't have hesitated to knock someone around for wasting a precious shell. Now...
I hate it! It's your fault!
You're thinking twice before you terrorize anyone?
And it'll give me cause to rearrange their faces next time they miss a shot!
Practice on these Morganas. Maybe it'll burn the urge out.
Like throwing moths at a candle.
@BATTLE
What's the story, Gnevny?
Scarlet Sails, as usual. I'm not so blind I can't read my favorite book.
I meant about the posters. But it's nice to see you relaxed.
I haven't memorized it yet. You should see my sister Boiky.
She's a big reader?
Of very specific books.

Fields.MenuText: We were talking about the posters.
Which ones?
Maybe the sailors would be interested in a book club.

Fields.DialogueText: You were talking about the posters. Then you let me derail the conversation.
Wall-to-wall politics. She's a bit of an obsessive.
They could never appreciate it as I do. I don't need to give you more reasons to reprimand me.
Now, I held up my end of the bargain. You'll find here a list of each poster and how far away I could discern the lettering.
Nyet! Find someone in port to do this or forget it.
This is a little ridiculous. The crew are going to see you with glasses no matter what.
@BATTLE
Excellent. I'll send this over to the naval surgeon and--
They will know when I am ready for them to know. I'm not risking this leaking to anyone aboard.
*ALARM*
Conversation over, Kapitan. Get me my prescription and I'll get you results.
The sooner the better.
*SPLASH*
Chert.
What's the hunt? Morgana divers?
Pike. Seal, if I'm lucky.
With a firearm.
I can't catch a seal with a fishing rod.

Fields.MenuText: We've got food of our own. You don't need to hunt for us.
You think the crew might want to help?
Maybe you haven't tried a big enough rod.

Fields.DialogueText: Why would I hunt for anyone but myself?
This isn't about them.
I'd rather bully some whaler into doing my work for me.
This is an eyesight thing.
That's definitely true. You bounced back from the battle of Tsushima, after all.
Ever sit wrong and have to walk around a bit to restore feeling in your leg? It's like that.
More than an eyesight "thing." It's a Comrade thing. We Baltic Fleet girls don't take defeat lying down.
We don't talk about Tsushima.
Well, then how--
We take our licking and do better next time. Now, quiet... I think I see a seal!
*ALARM*
And there it goes. Curse the day they invented Rusalki.
Think your eyes are up to the fight?
Konechno. A Rusalka is bigger than a seal.
@BATTLE
Package for you, Gnevny. Says it's from--
Quiet! Give it here!
Relax. Nobody's paying attention.
That's exactly what people say before their enemies find them out. Besides, everyone pays attention to me.
What do you think?
They match my dress.

Fields.MenuText: What about your eyesight?
You're welcome.
I'm not trying to help you accessorize.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, the horizon is less blurry now. Not that it was hindering me before.
Da, Kapitan, I have you to thank for doing this for me. Not that you needed to.
I don't need that kind of help. My fashion is the envy of the Baltic Fleet. The Black Sea Fleet, too.
Ready to test these out in battle?
Are you crazy!? People will think I'm weak!
Hmm.
Weren't you falling apart not that long ago?
N-not that anyone could tell!
I seem to remember the crew complaining about leaks and groaning metal.
Zhdanov amateurs. Can't even find decent shipbuilders to copy from.
*ALARM*
Make a decision.
I'm working on it!
@BATTLE
Steady, Gnevny. The Morganas aren't messing around.
That'd be a first. I've only gotten stronger since we last encountered them!
You don't say.
I do say! Molchi!
@BATTLE
Let's see them try and take me on again!

Fields.MenuText: Funny you should mention seeing them.
What do you think turned the tide?
You did really well, Gnevny. I'm proud of you.

Fields.DialogueText: What are you trying to imply, Kapitan? Don't take the shine off my victory!
That tide didn't turn, Kapitan! It blew right over those witches.
Happy to be of service! Stick around and you'll learn a lot.
Tell me honestly, Gnevny. Do you think your glasses helped?
I guess it is nice to see where the ocean ends and the sky begins.
You couldn't before?
Did I need to? It was the Rusalki I was shooting at!
And now you're hitting them a hell of a lot more often.
I was always hitting them. It was just a matter of getting better tools to hit them with.
As long as you're doing your best, Gnevny. That's all that matters to me.
I must matter a very great deal! You'd be swimming without me.
I'd be bored to tears without you.
Kakoy? I mean... of course you would!
Ha! Take that, you overgrown sea dog!
Fishing again?
Sealing! Look at them scatter!
I hope I didn't accidentally wreck the ecosystem.
Don't take credit for my accomplishments! Besides, the Rusalki are much more dangerous to your world than I am.

Fields.MenuText: It's your world too, you know.
How's your catch rate?
Are you at least sharing your catches with the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, it is your world. We Comrades have to live in it.
Improving. What's your point?
Those who have earned it.
Anything.
Keep the glasses under your hat. I don't know what I'd do if one of your sailors saw me and started talking.
Knowing you, you'd turn them into a figurehead.
Can you do me one more favor?
Mozhet byt'. But I really don't know. I'm still working on predicting my own actions in the short term when provoked.
That might be the most self-aware you've been this entire tour.
It's a warning! I choose my words for maximum impact.
We're coming up on some Morganas. Throw some of that impact into your shots.
Of course! Do I look like one of those Folgore-class layabouts?
@BATTLE
All right, tell me what happened.
I was in the mess hall eating with some of the off-duty crew. They were all enjoying the seal I'd caught.
I thought you were hunting for yourself.
I was! I need the crew to be fed and ready for action.
So when did the violence start?
One of them remarked on how much better he was eating now that... now that... Grr! I can't even say it!

Fields.MenuText: Heh. Come on, that's a little funny.
I'm sure he didn't mean anything by it.
That's certainly rude.

Fields.DialogueText: You're lucky you're my kapitan.
An idiot doesn't have to know what a gun does to pick it up and shoot someone.
He's had plenty of time in the infirmary to think on it.
So that's when the first punch was thrown.
It was... strange, Kapitan. Someone told him to shut up, and then someone asked if that person had a problem. Then someone told him to shut up too.
Take your time.
... Now that Comrade Four-Eyes had taken up hunting.
Wait. You didn't hit him?
Nyet. That was one of the crew who spoke in my defense.
I'm impressed, Gnevny. Not long ago you wouldn't have hesitated.
I know. I hate it!
*ALARM*
Don't let them get you down. We've got some Morganas who would love to be target practice for you.
They're the next best thing...
@BATTLE
Chert, chert, chert, chert, chert... I can't be out already!
Cigarettes run dry?
I never thought I'd see the day.

Fields.MenuText: You normally keep a tight grip on your supplies.
Should we be worried?
Going to be able to wait for your contact?

Fields.DialogueText: That's to make sure other people don't waste them!
Only if I can't bum one off the crew. Someone's got to be holding out on me.
I've endured worse. Probably.
Of course it isn't.
Good, we agree.
I may have been burning through them quicker than I usually do. But it's not my fault.
Are you worried about something?
I'm never worried. I might be... apprehensive.
Nobody's going to judge you for wearing glasses, Gnevny.
Everyone judged me for leaking. Why is this any different?
*ALARM*
If anyone gets on your case about it, they'll have me to answer to. Especially in the middle of a battle, when there are more important things to focus on.
Hmph. Not that I need defending, but... Thank you, Kapitan. Seal jerky for some energy?
All yours.
@BATTLE
Back in cigarettes, I see.
I stocked up.
Your contact's going to be away for a while?
My contact is still in the infirmary. I'll find a new one.
Wait, he was the one who called you--
Don't say it!

Fields.MenuText: I'll have a few questions for him once he's back on his feet.
Sorry.
It's just a name.

Fields.DialogueText: I'd like to be there when you ask them. Cleaning my gun.
No need. I know you know better.
And my fist is just five fingers.
But it got me thinking. I was so concerned about my glasses leaking... only to spill the beans to my cigarette man.
And after all the trouble you went to to get me not to talk about it.
You are different! You're a kapitan. He was... was...
Do you remember his name, by chance?
... I remember that he always had cigarettes.
That might be part of the problem.
We've got a Rusalka problem, Kapitan. I'll think of that other one later.
@BATTLE
You vented your secrets to your dealer?
He doesn't talk much, and I liked it that way. Or at least I thought he didn't talk much.
What were those battle cries during the fight, Gnevny?
What? Oh, yes! That was advice from some of the other girls. They said it helps keep the crew together.
It reminds them the guns they are firing and the deck they stand on are a part of me. That I am in the fight as well, and they'd better treat me right.
That makes sense to me. I can see how they might feel you are a passenger otherwise.
I used to hear them talk about me as if I was... a mascot. Something to be paraded around. That's happened less and less lately.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds frustrating. Do you want me to talk about this to the crew for you?
Sounds like they're learning how to deal with you.
I suppose you simply have to prove you are more than a mascot, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: No, no, that would not help at all. I think it is important that we handle this for ourselves.
They're giving me less cause to knock heads, that's certain.
I've done that time and time again. It's not my fault if they have yet to catch up with me.
I don't think I've ever known you to ask for advice from the other Belles, come to think of it.
Some of them don't have to fight to keep their crew in line. I don't know why I got stuck with the unruly ones, but I whipped them into shape.
I was just curious about how they did things. Not that I'd copy them.
See where we're headed, Gnevny?
I see the witches. Just watch me - they'll never know what hit them!
@BATTLE
Keep being curious. It's helping.
What was that in the mess earlier?
What was what?
The speech you gave.
Nothing you need worry about. I just beat some unruly behavior out of the crew, is all. Had to make an example of the worst of them.

Fields.MenuText: That's not what I heard.
We could put them ashore next time we are able. We don't want them to cause trouble in the Fleet.
They seemed fine to me.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you sure? Maybe you need to beat some unruly behavior out of your ears.
I don't think they need to be shuffled aside. They're bent, not broken.
Not all scars are on the outside.
It sounded like an apology to me.
This doesn't leave the ship.
What doesn't?
I was... surprised, I admit. When the crew came to my defense. My cigarette man was only joking, he said.
After speaking to him in the infirmary... well, I think I believe him. Maybe it wasn't necessary for anyone to get hurt.
So I decided if he could apologize for offending, then so could I. Fair's fair.
Good for you, Gnevny. You've come pretty far.
I was always capable of mercy! The crew earned it.
*ALARM*
Fortunately, it can be turned on and off.
@BATTLE
You know, it occurs to me that I've never seen you with your glasses outside of combat.
Do you walk around with your gun in your hand?
You've been known to.
Da, but that is to keep the peace. My glasses serve a specific purpose.
... Your gun serves nonspecific purposes?
Peacekeeping. Hunting. Sleep aid.

Fields.MenuText: What was that last one?
At least your trigger discipline's impeccable.
That's perfectly normal, Gnevny. Lots of people have glasses for reading or driving.

Fields.DialogueText: What last one? You're hearing things!
Of course it is! You should see some of my sisters. And they call me angry...
The practice may be normal, but I am better than normal. Never forget it.
I won't apologize for doubting you, Kapitan. I maintain healthy skepticism of everyone and everything. But your suggestion has helped.
Save your sentimentality for after the battle. I'll let you in on a little secret in the meantime. See my new scope?
@BATTLE
There are definitely military applications. But I think it's gotten you closer to the crew as well. I'm happy to see that.
Are those...?
I told you, Kapitan. My glasses serve a specific purpose.
*ALARM*
Ha! Arthur Gray, how daring you are!
Find a bookmark, Gnevny - we're about to be in a fight.
You look rough, Gnevny. I saw you take some hits on the breakthrough. How are you holding up?
I have been better, Kapitan. The Rusalki got in a few lucky shots.
Can't dodge them all, eh?
Well, it's not my fault. Our enemies are notorious cheaters.
No shame in taking a couple of hits. It happens to everyone.
That's what you humans are for.

Fields.MenuText: I like to think we're good for more than that.
We've got to keep you going no matter what.
That and keeping you in cigarettes.

Fields.DialogueText: Even the hero of a story doesn't spend all his time moving the plot forward.
That's what I like to hear.
I consider that part of maintenance.
You know we're going to do everything we can to keep you fighting, right?
I should hope so. You can't afford to lose me.
You're a good destroyer, it's true. But don't lose sight of who you are because of what you are. I haven't.
Da, da, da. I've read this a dozen times anyway.
@BATTLE
And who am I?
A friend. You're allowed to have those at war. There's more to it than maintenance.
... Thank you, Kapitan. I... you've definitely made it easier to look at things that way.
What was so hard about it?
A fight is how you know you're alive. But to be constantly evaluated... judged... like those Folgore girls. Won't we replace them? And who replaces us after?
You're not the best destroyer out there, not forever. But you're the best Gnevny. There's no replacing you.
Sure am. You're not a bad kapitan yourself.
